ref: 9181 baṣkáya ep. of vatsá -- RV. i 164, 5: (Oldenberg) ʻ grown up ʼ, (Sāyaṇa) ʻ one year old ʼ. 2. baṣkayiṇī -- , ˚yaṇī -- f. ʻ cow with a young calf ʼ lex. [Cf. báṣkiha -- VS., vá˚ MaitrS. ʻ having calved long since (?) ʼ. -- NIA. words point on the one hand to a calf weaned (or old enough to be) and on the other to a cow whose milk is beginning to fail when its calf is grown. Mahīdhara's interpretation of báṣkiha -- as ʻ ciraprasūtā ʼ may therefore be correct (and so intended by BR with ʻ effetus ʼ in literal sense, but taken as ʻ old, decrepit ʼ by MW). Perh. a ʻ defective ʼ word ʻ weak, young ʼ and cognate with bāṣka -- ʻ weak ʼ Sū. (quoted by EWA ii 422) with the long ā that appears in P.]
P. vākhṛā, bākhṛā (< *vāṣka -- ) ʻ having given milk for some time (of cow or buffalo), rich (of its milk) ʼ;
H. bākhṛī, bākhlī f. ʻ cow or buffalo which has been five months in calf or which calved five months ago, young cow or buffalo ʼ;
G. bākhṛī f. ʻ cow or buffalo about to cease giving milk after a long time ʼ;
M. bhākaḍ ʻ ceasing to give milk ʼ; --
N. bakernu ʻ young calf just weaned ʼ, bakerni ʻ ceasing to give milk ʼ.
